tools.resources:
* Neff, K. D., & Germer, C. K. (2013). [A pilot study and randomized controlled trial of the mindful self‐compassion program](https://doi.org/10.1002/jclp.21923). Journal of clinical psychology, 69:1.
* Neff, K. D., & Vonk, R. (2009). [Self‐compassion versus global self‐esteem: Two different ways of relating to oneself](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-6494.2008.00537.x). Journal of personality, 77:1.Germer, C.K. and Neff, K.D. (2013), [Self‐Compassion in Clinical Practice](https://doi.org/10.1002/jclp.22021). Journal of Clinical Psychology, 69.
* Neff, Kristin. (2015). [Self-Compassion – the Proven Power of Being Kind to Yourself](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0061733520/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0061733520&linkCode=as2&tag=selfcompassio-20&linkId=24d99d0532e24ea2d4913ee18222a6b1). William Morrow, New York, NY.
* Neff, K. D., Tóth-Király, I., Yarnell, L., Arimitsu, K., Castilho, P., Ghorbani, N. ,Mantios, M. (2019). [Examining the Factor Structure of the Self-Compassion Scale using exploratory SEM bifactor analysis in 20 diverse samples: Support for use of a total score and six subscale scores](https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0000629). Psychological Assessment, 31:1.
tools.name: Self compassion
tools.description: This course helps build your self compassion so you can enjoy life without being ruled by fear and self doubt. You will learn how to identify when you are overly critical of yourself, understand why you do it and how it affects you.

tools.name: Purposeful Leadership
tools.description: A course tested by Paralympic coaches and space station personnel, designed to help you grow in your ability to lead in all areas of your life thanks to engaging exercises and daily quests.
tools.resources:
* Dreyfus, H. L. (2011). Chapter 2. In On the Internet: Thinking in action. London: Routledge.

* Bass, B. M. (1990). From transactional to transformational leadership: Learning to share the vision. Organizational Dynamics, 18(3), 19-31. doi:10.1016/0090-2616(90)90061-s

tools.name: Acting with purpose
tools.description: A course that provides three tools to create a healthier and more constructive relationship to the global and societal challenges we face through individual action.
tools.resources:
* Hayes, Steven. (2005). [Get out of your mind and into your life. The new acceptance and commitment therapy.](https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/25348.Get_Out_of_Your_Mind_and_Into_Your_Life) New Harbinger Publications, Oakland, California

* Hayes, S. C., Luoma, J. B., Bond, F. W., Masuda, A., & Lillis, J. (2006). [Acceptance and commitment therapy: Model, processes and outcomes.](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0005796705002147) Behaviour Research and Therapy, 44(1).

* Bond, F. W., & Dowling, J. R. (Manuscript in preparation) Actively Living as an Individual Vitally Embodied (ALIVE).

* Eifert, G. H., & Forsyth, J. P. (2005). [Acceptance and commitment therapy for anxiety disorders: A practitioner's treatment guide to using mindfulness, acceptance, and values-based behavior change strategies.](https://www.newharbinger.com/9781572244276/acceptance-and-commitment-therapy-for-anxiety-disorders/) New Harbinger Publications, Oakland, California.

tools.name: Dealing with stress
tools.description: What would life look like if it was less stressful? In this course you'll get to explore ways to improve your ability to deal with stress and live a life that is more meaningful to you.
tools.resources:
* Flaxman, PE & Bond FW. (2010) [A randomised worksite comparison of acceptance and commitment therapy and stress inoculation training](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0005796710000872). Behaviour Research and Therapy, 48:8.

* Lloyd, J, Bond, FW & Flaxman, PE. (2013) [The value of psychological flexibility: Examining psychological mechanisms underpinning a cognitive behavioural therapy intervention for burnout](https://doi.org/10.1080/02678373.2013.782157), Work & Stress, 27:2.

* Frögéli, E, Djordjevic, A, Rudman, A, Livheim, F & Gustavsson, P. (2016) [A randomized controlled pilot trial of acceptance and commitment training (ACT) for preventing stress-related ill health among future nurses](https://doi.org/10.1080/10615806.2015.1025765), Anxiety, Stress & Coping, 29:2

* Bond, FW & Bunce, D. (2000) [Mediators of change in emotion-focused and problem-focused worksite stress management interventions](https://doi.org/10.1037/1076-8998.5.1.156). Journal of Occupational Health Psychology, 5:1.

* Ek, D, Hedensjö, B & Livheim, F (2017). [Tid att leva: ett tioveckors program för stresshantering med ACT och medveten närvaro](https://www.nok.se/titlar/akademisk-psykologi/tid-att-leva/). Natur & Kultur, Stockholm.

tools.name: Nourishing relationships
tools.description: This course explores several powerful ways to strengthen and deepen your relationships. In times of hardship, few things are as important as experiencing deep connection to others.
tools.resources:
* Kanter, J. W., Kuczynski, A. M., Tsai, M., & Kohlenberg, R. J. (2018). A brief contextual behavioral intervention to improve relationships: A randomized trial. Journal of contextual behavioral science, 10, 75-84.

* Kanter, J. W., Kuczynski, A. M., Manbeck, K. E., Corey, M. D., & Wallace, E. C. (2020). An integrative contextual behavioral model of intimate relations. Journal of Contextual Behavioral Science.

* Aron, A., Melinat, E., Aron, E. N., Vallone, R. D., & Bator, R. J. (1997). The experimental generation of interpersonal closeness: A procedure and some preliminary findings. Personality and social psychology bulletin, 23(4), 363-377.

* Collins, N. L., & Miller, L. C. (1994). Self-disclosure and liking: a meta-analytic review. Psychological bulletin, 116(3), 457.

* Oswald, D. L., Clark, E. M., & Kelly, C. M. (2004). Friendship maintenance: An analysis of individual and dyad behaviors. Journal of Social and clinical psychology, 23(3), 413-441.

* Reis, H. T., Shaver, P., Duck, S., & Hay, D. F. (1988). Intimacy as an interpersonal process. Handbook of personal relationships.

* Tsai, M., Hardebeck, E., Ramos, F. P., Turlove, H., Nordal‐Jonsson, K., Vongdala, A., ... & Kohlenberg, R. J. (2020). Helping couples connect during the COVID‐19 pandemic: A pilot randomised controlled trial of an awareness, courage, and love intervention. Applied Psychology: Health and Well‐Being, 12(4), 1140-1156.

tools.name: Deepening relationships
tools.description: This course explores how to grow relationships and take bold steps in letting your true self come to life in relationships. Whether you want to strengthen a relationship to a friend, partner, colleague or family member, this course can help you get going.
tools.resources:
* Kanter, J. W., Kuczynski, A. M., Tsai, M., & Kohlenberg, R. J. (2018). A brief contextual behavioral intervention to improve relationships: A randomized trial. Journal of contextual behavioral science, 10, 75-84.

* Kanter, J. W., Kuczynski, A. M., Manbeck, K. E., Corey, M. D., & Wallace, E. C. (2020). An integrative contextual behavioral model of intimate relations. Journal of Contextual Behavioral Science.

* Aron, A., Melinat, E., Aron, E. N., Vallone, R. D., & Bator, R. J. (1997). The experimental generation of interpersonal closeness: A procedure and some preliminary findings. Personality and social psychology bulletin, 23(4), 363-377.

* Collins, N. L., & Miller, L. C. (1994). Self-disclosure and liking: a meta-analytic review. Psychological bulletin, 116(3), 457.

* Oswald, D. L., Clark, E. M., & Kelly, C. M. (2004). Friendship maintenance: An analysis of individual and dyad behaviors. Journal of Social and clinical psychology, 23(3), 413-441.

* Reis, H. T., Shaver, P., Duck, S., & Hay, D. F. (1988). Intimacy as an interpersonal process. Handbook of personal relationships.

* Tsai, M., Hardebeck, E., Ramos, F. P., Turlove, H., Nordal‐Jonsson, K., Vongdala, A., ... & Kohlenberg, R. J. (2020). Helping couples connect during the COVID‐19 pandemic: A pilot randomised controlled trial of an awareness, courage, and love intervention. Applied Psychology: Health and Well‐Being, 12(4), 1140-1156.

tools.name: ALIVE: Daily quests – pilot
tools.description: This is a pilot testing of the application of a new psychological model called ALIVE. The acronym ALIVE stands for Actively Living and Interconnecting Vitally in one’s Embedded-world, which essentially means to engage in doing what’s important to you, connect with others and have a sense of belonging.
tools.actions: * [Try ALIVE: Daily quests – pilot in the 29k app!](https://app.29k.org/alive-daily-quests-idg)

tools.name: Meaning-making in a crisis
tools.description: In this course you will take the first step on a journey to a more meaningful life in these times of turmoil, based on what really matters to you, practice acceptance and work on finding your values.
tools.actions: * [Try Meaning-making in a crisis in the 29k app!](https://app.29k.org/meaning-making-in-a-crisis-idg)

tools.name: Values
tools.description: In our everyday life, we easily lose touch with what matters to us. This is especially true when we’re dealing with a challenging situation. This course is focused on connecting to our core values as a powerful tool to take meaningful action in every moment of our lives.

tools.name: Coping with crisis
tools.description: Are you in a tough spot fearing what the future might hold? This course will give you tools for coping better with change. You’ll learn a range of psychological tools that are proven to reduce the effects of overwhelm, anxiety and stress.
tools.resources:
* Hayes SC, Pistorello J, Levin ME. [Acceptance and commitment therapy as a unified model of behavior change](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0011000012460836). The Counseling Psychologist. 2012;40(7).

* Villatte JL, Vilardaga R, Villatte M, Plumb Vilardaga JC, Atkins DC, Hayes SC. [Acceptance and Commitment Therapy modules: Differential impact on treatment processes and outcomes](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4752868/). Behav Res Ther. 2016;77.

* Rickardsson, J, Gentili, C, Holmström, L, et al. (2021). [Internet-delivered acceptance and commitment therapy as microlearning for chronic pain: A randomized controlled trial with 1-year follow-up](https://doi.org/10.1002/ejp.1723). European Journal of Pain vol 25.

skills.name: Inner compass
skills.description: Having a deeply felt sense of responsibility and commitment to values and purposes relating to the good of the whole.

skills.name: Integrity and Authenticity
skills.description: A commitment and ability to act with sincerity, honesty and integrity.

skills.name: Openness and Learning mindset
skills.description: Having a basic mindset of curiosity and a willingness to be vulnerable and embrace change and grow.

skills.name: Self-awareness
skills.description: Ability to be in reflective contact with own thoughts, feelings and desires; having a realistic self-image and ability to regulate oneself.

skills.name: Presence
skills.description: Ability to be in the here and now, without judgement and in a state of open-ended presence.

skills.name: Critical thinking
skills.description: Skills in critically reviewing the validity of views, evidence and plans.

skills.name: Complexity awareness
skills.description: Understanding of and skills in working with complex and systemic conditions and causalities.

skills.name: Perspective skills
skills.description: Skills in seeking, understanding and actively making use of insights from contrasting perspectives.

skills.name: Sense-making
skills.description: Skills in seeing patterns, structuring the unknown and being able to consciously create stories.

skills.name: Long-term orientation and Visioning
skills.description: Long-term orientation and ability to formulate and sustain commitment to visions relating to the larger context.

skills.name: Appreciation
skills.description: Relating to others and to the world with a basic sense of appreciation, gratitude and joy.

skills.name: Connectedness
skills.description: Having a keen sense of being connected with and/or being a part of a larger whole, such as a community, humanity or global ecosystem.

skills.name: Humility
skills.description: Being able to act in accordance with the needs of the situation without concern for one's own importance.

skills.name: Empathy and Compassion
skills.description: Ability to relate to others, oneself and nature with kindness, empathy and compassion and address related suffering

skills.name: Communication skills
skills.description: Ability to really listen to others, to foster genuine dialogue, to advocate own views skillfully, to manage conflicts constructively and to adapt communication to diverse groups.

skills.name: Co-creation skills
skills.description: Skills and motivation to build, develop and facilitate collaborative relationships with diverse stake-holders, characterized by psychological safety and genuine co-creation.

skills.name: Inclusive mindset and intercultural competence
skills.description: Willingness and competence to embrace diversity and include people and collectives with different views and backgrounds.

skills.name: Trust
skills.description: Ability to show trust and to create and maintain trusting relationships.

skills.name: Mobilization skills
skills.description: Skills in inspiring and mobilizing others to engage in shared purposes.

skills.name: Courage
skills.description: Ability to stand up for values, make decisions, take decisive action and, if need be, challenge and disrupt existing structures and views.

skills.name: Creativity
skills.description: Ability to generate and develop original ideas, innovate and being willing to disrupt conventional patterns.

skills.name: Optimism
skills.description: Ability to sustain and communicate a sense of hope, positive attitude and confidence in the possibility of meaningful change.

skills.name: Perseverance
skills.description: Ability to sustain engagement and remain determined and patient even when efforts take a long time to bear fruit.

categories.name: Relating
categories.description: Caring for Others and the World
